title: Infer the secreted protein activity from gene expression in bulk level
text: current case includes differential expression profiles anti-IFNG treatment control samples.
code: library(SecAct)  # prepare expression matrix exprPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/IFNG_GSE100093.diff.gz") expr <- read.csv(exprPath, row.names=1, check.names=F)  # run SecAct to infer activity; ~3 mins res <- SecAct.inference(expr)  # show activity head(res$zscore)  ##         Anti-IFNG.15day Anti-IFNG.57day ## A1BG        27.41700606       15.560484 ## A2M         -1.00132544        3.703776 ## A2ML1       -5.70139021       -5.585635 ## AADACL2     -0.03412573        8.556714 ## ABHD15       7.91357240        3.360326 ## ABI3BP      -1.57170759       -4.292832  # show IFNG activity res$zscore["IFNG",]  ## Anti-IFNG.15day Anti-IFNG.57day  ##       -10.76148       -30.50151

title: Infer the secreted protein activity from gene expression in bulk level
text: case aims infer secreted protein activity pancreatic cancer RNA-Seq cohorts CPTAC. Note: control samples, recommend normalize expression values gene zero mean across samples. words, just use expression matrix control.
code: library(SecAct)  # read expression matrix exprPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/CPTAC_PDAC_Tumor.csv.gz") expr <- read.csv(exprPath, row.names=1, check.names=F)  exprControlPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/CPTAC_PDAC_Normal.csv.gz") exprControl <- read.csv(exprControlPath, row.names=1, check.names=F)  # normalize expression matrix expr <- expr - rowMeans(exprControl)  # run SecAct to infer activity res <- SecAct.inference(expr, lambda=10000, nrand=1000)  # show activity head(res$zscore) # normalize the expression values of each gene to zero mean across samples expr <- expr - rowMeans(expr)

title: Secreted protein signaling activity change between two phenotypes
text: section shows read expression matrix R environment separate samples treatment control groups.
code: library(SecAct)  # prepare expression matrix dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/") expr <- read.csv(paste0(dataPath,"GSE100093.IFNG.expr.gz"), sep="\t")  # read meta infomation meta <- read.csv(paste0(dataPath,"GSE100093.IFNG.meta"), sep="\t")  # subset treatment and control groups expr.treatment <- expr[, meta[,"Treatment"]=="Anti-IFNG"] expr.control <- expr[, meta[,"Treatment"]=="Control"]

title: Secreted protein signaling activity change between two phenotypes
text: input expr.treatment expr.control SecAct.activity.inference infer activity change secreted proteins treatment control groups. SecAct calculates OVERALL activity change two phenotypes default setting .singleSampleLevel = FALSE. can also obtain activity change SINGLE sample expr.treatment setting .singleSampleLevel = TRUE. note, samples paired, just change default setting .paired = FALSE TRUE. positive value means secreted protein high activity treatment group negative value means secreted protein high activity control group. can see IFNG activity reduced expected, consistent treatment group receiving anti-IFNG therapy.
code: # infer activity change; ~2 mins res <- SecAct.activity.inference(   inputProfile = expr.treatment,    inputProfile_control = expr.control,   is.singleSampleLevel = FALSE,   is.paired = FALSE )  # res$zscore stores activity change act.change <- res$zscore  # show activity change head(act.change) # show IFNG activity change act.change["IFNG","Change"]

title: Secreted protein signaling activity change between two phenotypes
text: User can visualize secreted proteins interest using SecAct.bar.plot. , select top - -regulated secreted proteins (SPs) treatment control examples.  positive value means secreted protein high activity treatment group negative value means secreted protein high activity control group.
code: # select the top secreted proteins n <- 10 up.SPs <- names(sort(act.change[,"Change"],decreasing=T))[1:n] down.SPs <- names(sort(act.change[,"Change"]))[1:n]  SPs <- c(up.SPs, down.SPs) # user can assign any secreted proteins to SPs  # generate a vector fg.vec <- act.change[SPs,"Change"]  # visualize in bar plot SecAct.bar.plot(fg.vec, title="Activity Change (treatment vs control)")

title: Secreted protein signaling activity change between two phenotypes
text: already differential profile (signature) instead expression matrix two phenotypes, can directly run SecAct.activity.inference .differential = TRUE.
code: # compare two phenotypes to generate a differential profile expr.diff <- matrix(   data = rowMeans(expr.treatment) - rowMeans(expr.control),    ncol = 1,   dimnames = list(     row_names = rownames(expr.treatment),     col_names = "Diff"   ) )  # Run a differential profile; ~2 mins res <- SecAct.activity.inference(   inputProfile = expr.diff,    is.differential = TRUE )  # res$zscore stores activity change act.change <- res$zscore  # show activity change head(act.change)

title: Clinical relevance of secreted proteins in a large patient cohort
text: section shows read expression matrix R environment.
code: library(SecAct)  # prepare expression matrix dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/") expr <- read.table(paste0(dataPath,"Pancreatic_Nivolumab_Padron2022.logTPM.gz"), check.names=F)

title: Clinical relevance of secreted proteins in a large patient cohort
text: use SecAct.activity.inference infer signaling activity secreted proteins across patient samples. data control samples (e.g., normal patients), can assign inputProfile_control. SecAct normalize gene’s expression values control samples, .e., substracting mean gene expression control samples. available, just set inputProfile_control=NULL (default). SecAct normalize expression values gene zero mean across input profiles. words, mean gene expression input profiles regarded control. inferred protein activity relative measure. positive value indicates high activity corresponding patients, negative value signifies low activity.
code: # infer activity; ~2 mins res <- SecAct.activity.inference(inputProfile=expr, inputProfile_control=NULL)  # res$zscore stores activity act <- res$zscore  # show activity act[1:6,1:3]  ##                  2          3           6 ## A1BG    -27.879835 -24.805532 -13.1475409 ## A2M       6.688479   5.891316  14.5120252 ## A2ML1     4.482488  -2.028074   5.5316736 ## AADACL2  -1.188018  -2.029080  -0.1938462 ## ABHD15  -14.462520 -13.212992  -8.5294933 ## ABI3BP   20.991414  14.093015  25.9819458

title: Clinical relevance of secreted proteins in a large patient cohort
text: next calculate signaling risk score z secreted protein linking activity levels clinical data. clinical file, please make sure name 1st 2nd columns “Time” “Event”, respectively. SecAct.coxph.regression conduct Cox proportional hazard (PH) regression, risk scores represented z-scores (Coef / StdErr) two-sided Wald test. note, clinical covariates (e.g., age, gender, stage) also considered regression available. risk score z, positive value means secreted protein associated poorer survival negative value means secreted protein associated better survival.
code: # read clinical infomation clinical <- read.table(paste0(dataPath,"Pancreatic_Nivolumab_Padron2022.OS_Nivo+Sotiga+Chemo"))  head(clinical)  ##    Time Event Age Gender ECOG ## 8   834     0  55      1    0 ## 13   28     1  60      0    1 ## 15  273     1  69      0    0 ## 22  159     1  69      0    1 ## 24  569     0  62      0    0 ## 25  264     1  66      1    1  # compute risk score riskMat <- SecAct.coxph.regression(act, clinical)  head(riskMat)  ##         risk score z     p value ## A1BG       -2.187803 0.028683943 ## A2M        -3.372297 0.000745439 ## A2ML1       1.668025 0.095310824 ## AADACL2    -1.960305 0.049960191 ## ABHD15     -2.511890 0.012008638 ## ABI3BP     -1.679394 0.093075338

title: Clinical relevance of secreted proteins in a large patient cohort
text: User can visualize secreted proteins interest using SecAct.lollipop.plot. , select top high low risk secreted proteins (SPs), associated poorer better survival, respectively.
code: # select the top secreted proteins n <- 10 high.risk.SPs <- names(sort(riskMat[,"risk score z"],decreasing=T))[1:n] low.risk.SPs <- names(sort(riskMat[,"risk score z"]))[1:n]  SPs <- c(high.risk.SPs, low.risk.SPs) # user can assign any secreted proteins to SPs  # generate a vector fg.vec <- riskMat[SPs,"risk score z"]  # visualize in lollipop plot SecAct.lollipop.plot(fg.vec, title="Risk score z")

title: Clinical relevance of secreted proteins in a large patient cohort
text: User can select secreted protein interest draw survival curve using SecAct.survival.plot. activity cutoff selected maximizing difference high low activity patient groups.
code: # Take secreted protein WNT7B as an example riskMat["WNT7B",]  ## risk score z      p value  ## 3.3252642698 0.0008833476   # visualize in survival plot SecAct.survival.plot(act, clinical, "WNT7B", x.title="Overall (Days)")

title: Secreted protein activity difference between two phenotypes
text: section shows read expression matrix R environment separate treatment control patient group.
code: library(SecAct)  # prepare expression matrix dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/") expr <- read.csv(paste0(dataPath,"GSE100093.IFNG.expr.gz"), sep="\t")  # read meta infomation meta <- read.csv(paste0(dataPath,"GSE100093.IFNG.meta"), sep="\t")  # subset treatment and control group expr.treatment <- expr[, meta[,"Treatment"]=="Anti-IFNG"] expr.control <- expr[, meta[,"Treatment"]=="Control"]

title: Secreted protein activity difference between two phenotypes
text: input expr.treatment expr.control SecAct.activity.inference infer activity difference >1000 secreted proteins treatment control groups. SecAct calculates OVERALL activity difference two phenotypes default setting .singleSampleLevel = FALSE. can also obtain activity change sample expr.treatment setting .singleSampleLevel = TRUE. note, samples paired, just change defult setting .paired = FALSE TRUE. positive value means secreted protein high activity treatment group negative value means secreted protein high activity control group. can see IFNG activity reduced expected, consistent treatment group receiving anti-IFNG therapy.
code: # infer activity difference; ~2 mins res <- SecAct.activity.inference(   inputProfile = expr.treatment,    inputProfile_control = expr.control,   is.singleSampleLevel = FALSE,   is.paired = FALSE )  # res$zscore stores activity difference act.diff <- res$zscore  # show activity difference head(act.diff)  ##              Diff ## A1BG    12.412416 ## A2M      1.654828 ## A2ML1   -7.130571 ## AADACL2  8.538400 ## ABHD15   1.720629 ## ABI3BP  -8.170191 # show IFNG activity difference act.diff["IFNG","Diff"]  ## [1] -35.67649

title: Secreted protein activity difference between two phenotypes
text: User can visualize secreted proteins interest using SecAct.bar.plot. , select top - -regulated secreted proteins (SPs) treatment control examples.  positive value means secreted protein high activity treatment group negative value means secreted protein high activity control group.
code: # select the top secreted proteins n <- 10 up.SPs <- names(sort(act.diff[,"Diff"],decreasing=T))[1:n] down.SPs <- names(sort(act.diff[,"Diff"]))[1:n]  SPs <- c(up.SPs, down.SPs) # user can assign any secreted proteins to SPs  # generate a vector fg.vec <- act.diff[SPs,"Diff"]  # visualize in bar plot SecAct.bar.plot(fg.vec, title="Activity Diff (treatment vs control)")

title: Secreted protein activity difference between two phenotypes
text: already differential profile (signature) instead expression matrix two phenotypes, can directly run SecAct.activity.inference .differential = TRUE.
code: # compare two phenotypes to get a differential profile expr.diff <- rowMeans(expr.treatment) - rowMeans(expr.control)  # generate input profile expr.diff <- as.matrix(expr.diff, ncol=1) colnames(expr.diff) <- "Diff"  # Run against to differential profile res <- SecAct.activity.inference(   inputProfile = expr.diff,    is.differential = TRUE )  # res$zscore stores activity difference act.diff <- res$zscore  # show activity difference head(act.diff)  ##              Diff ## A1BG    12.412416 ## A2M      1.654828 ## A2ML1   -7.130571 ## AADACL2  8.538400 ## ABHD15   1.720629 ## ABI3BP  -8.170191

title: Cell-cell communication mediated by secreted proteins from scRNA-Seq data
text: OV scRNA-Seq data stored Seurat object. information cell-type annotations anatomical sites stored columns MyCellType Groups meta.data Seurat object, respectively. Users can easily access using following code.
code: library(SecAct) library(Seurat)  # download data from https://zenodo.org/records/15006880/files/OV_scRNAseq_Seurat.rds # load scRNA-Seq data Seurat_obj <- readRDS("OV_scRNAseq_Seurat.rds")  # cell count table(Seurat_obj@meta.data[,"Groups"])  ## Metastatic    Primary  ##      18746      17589   # show UMAP plot my_cols <- c(     'B'='#C88888','CD4T'='#3288bd','CD8T'='#B95FBB','DC'='#63636d',     'Endothelial'='#D4D915','Fibroblast'='#66c2a5','Macrophage'='#ff9a36',     'NK'='#bb8761','Tex'='#fe666d','Treg'='#E6C122','Tumor'='#A4DFF2' )  p1 <- DimPlot(Seurat_obj, reduction = "umap", cols = my_cols, group.by = "MyCellType") p2 <- DimPlot(Seurat_obj, reduction = "umap", group.by = "Groups")  p1+p2

title: Cell-cell communication mediated by secreted proteins from scRNA-Seq data
text: SecAct performs three steps infer condition-specific cell-cell communication mediated secreted proteins: (1) assessing changes secreted protein expression cell type (defined source cell type) two conditions, (2) calculating changes secreted protein activity cell type (defined receiver cell type) two conditions, (3) linking source receiver cell types. running SecAct.CCC.scRNAseq, user need assign cellType_meta condition_meta column names cell-type annotation condition information Seurat_obj@meta.data, respectively. Also, claim case control conditions conditionCase conditionControl. User can find SecAct results Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output.
code: # infer activity; ~5 mins Seurat_obj <- SecAct.CCC.scRNAseq(   Seurat_obj,    cellType_meta="MyCellType",   condition_meta="Groups",    conditionCase="Metastatic",    conditionControl="Primary" )    # show output names(Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output)  ## [1] "SecretedProteinExpression" ## [2] "SecretedProteinActivity" ## [3] "SecretedProteinCCC"  # cell-cell communication results head(Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinCCC)

title: Cell-cell communication mediated by secreted proteins from scRNA-Seq data
text: provide two types visualization plot cell-cell communication, .e., heatmap circle plot. number heatmap represents count secreted proteins senders receivers.
code: SecAct.CCC.heatmap(Seurat_obj, row.sorted=TRUE, column.sorted=TRUE, colors_cellType=my_cols) SecAct.CCC.circle(Seurat_obj, colors_cellType=my_cols)

title: Cell-cell communication mediated by secreted proteins from scRNA-Seq data
text: User can select cell-cell communication interest Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinCCC visualize using SecAct.CCC.sankey. need assign values sender, secretedProtein, receiver.
code: sender <- c("Fibroblast","Macrophage","Endothelial","CD8T","Tex")  secretedProtein <- c(   "BGN","BMP1","COL15A1","COL18A1","COL1A1",   "COL1A2","CST3","FAP","FBN1","FN1",   "FSTL1","HSPG2","HTRA1","ISG15","MXRA5",   "POSTN","SERPING1","SPARC","TGFB1","TGFBI",   "THBS2","TIMP1","VCAN" )  receiver <- c("Tumor")  SecAct.CCC.sankey(   Seurat_obj,    colors_cellType = my_cols,    sender = sender,    secretedProtein = secretedProtein,    receiver = receiver )

title: Secreted protein signaling activity for distinct cell states from scRNA-Seq data
text: scRNA-Seq data CD4+ T cells stored Seurat object. Three cell states annotated dataset, .e., naive, central memory, helper 1-like.
code: library(SecAct) library(Seurat)  # load scRNA-Seq data dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/") Seurat_obj <- readRDS(paste0(dataPath,"OV_scRNAseq_CD4.rds"))  # cell count table(Seurat_obj@meta.data[,"Annotation"])  ## CD4_central_memory          CD4_naive       CD4_Th1_like  ##                402                 28                358   # show UMAP plot Seurat::DimPlot(Seurat_obj, reduction = "umap", group.by = "Annotation")

title: Secreted protein signaling activity for distinct cell states from scRNA-Seq data
text: loading scRNA-Seq data data, user can input Seurat_obj SecAct.activity.inference infer signaling activities secreted proteins various cell states. Also, need claim column meta matrix Seurat object cell state information. case, column name “Annotation” thus assign cellType_meta = "Annotation". User can find SecAct results Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity. inferred protein activity relative measure. positive value indicates high activity corresponding cell states, negative value signifies low activity.
code: # infer activity; ~2 mins Seurat_obj <- SecAct.activity.inference.scRNAseq(Seurat_obj, cellType_meta="Annotation")  # SecretedProteinActivity$zscore stores activity act <- Seurat_obj @misc $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity$zscore  # show activity head(act)  ##         CD4_central_memory  CD4_naive CD4_Th1_like ## A1BG            -0.5224152 -2.5877798   5.04170281 ## A2M             -1.8165372  1.0789818  -0.08903819 ## A2ML1            4.6669228 -3.4408384   1.41266953 ## AADACL2          2.2806474 -3.1300577   3.23410538 ## ABHD15           0.2801044  0.1688928  -0.55981830 ## ABI3BP          -0.7084864  1.5764300  -2.08041961

title: Secreted protein signaling activity for distinct cell states from scRNA-Seq data
text: User can visualize secreted proteins interest using SecAct.heatmap.plot. , select top active secreted proteins (SPs) cell state.
code: # select top secreted proteins n <- 10 SPs.1 <- names(sort(act[,1],decreasing=T))[1:n] SPs.2 <- names(sort(act[,2],decreasing=T))[1:n] SPs.3 <- names(sort(act[,3],decreasing=T))[1:n]  SPs <- c(SPs.1, SPs.2, SPs.3) # user can assign any secreted proteins to SPs  # subset act matrix fg.mat <- act[SPs,]  # visualize in heatmap SecAct.heatmap.plot(fg.mat)

title: Infer the secreted protein activity from single-cell RNA-Seq data
text: , use scRNA-Seq data includes T cell Normal Tumor tissue.
code: library(SecAct)  # load seurat object seuratPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/OV_GSE156728.rds") seurat_obj <- readRDS(seuratPath)  # extract count matrix expr <-  as.matrix(seurat_obj@assays$RNA@layers$counts) colnames(expr) <- rownames(seurat_obj@assays$RNA@cells) rownames(expr) <- rownames(seurat_obj@assays$RNA@features)  # normalize to TPM expr <- t(t(expr)*1e6/colSums(expr))  # transform to log space expr <- log2(expr/10 + 1)  # normalized with the control samples expr <- expr - rowMeans(expr) expr <- round(expr,3)  # run SecAct to infer activity res_sc <- SecAct.inference(expr) Sys.time() # show activity head(res$zscore)

title: Infer the secreted protein activity from single-cell RNA-Seq data
text: can integrate activity results Seurat object, visiualize .
code: res_sc_z <- t(res_sc$zscore) colnames(res_sc_z) <- paste0("activity_",colnames(res_sc_z))  seurat_obj@meta.data <- cbind(seurat_obj@meta.data,res_sc_z)  library(Seurat) library(ggplot2) library(patchwork)  p1 <- FeaturePlot(seurat_obj, reduction = "umap", features = c("activity_IFNG")) +   scale_colour_gradient2(low = "blue", mid = "white", high = "red") p2 <- DimPlot(seurat_obj, reduction = "umap", group.by = "cellType") p3 <- VlnPlot(seurat_obj, features = c("activity_IFNG"), )  p1|p2|p3

what: Read ST data to an SpaCET object
title: Infer secreted protein activity in spatial transcriptomics data
text: dataset includes two endometrial cancer patients treated anti-Netrin-1 (NTN1) compound. Netrin-1 secreted glycoprotein plays critical roles angiogenesis cell survival, blocking NTN1 inhibits tumor growth. patient pre- -treatment tumor samples, respectively. read ST data R, user can create SpaCET object using create.SpaCET.object.10X.
code: library(SpaCET)  # set the path to the data folder. dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/")  # load ST data to create an SpaCET object. # read on-treatment sample visiumPath <- paste0(dataPath,"UCEC_On/") SpaCET_obj_on <- create.SpaCET.object.10X(visiumPath = visiumPath) SpaCET_obj_on <- SpaCET.quality.control(SpaCET_obj_on)  # read pre-treatment sample visiumPath <- paste0(dataPath,"UCEC_Pre/") SpaCET_obj_pre <- create.SpaCET.object.10X(visiumPath = visiumPath) SpaCET_obj_pre <- SpaCET.quality.control(SpaCET_obj_pre)

title: Infer secreted protein activity in spatial transcriptomics data
text: loading ST data, user can run SecAct.inference infer activities 1000 secreted proteins across spot. note, analyze -treatment sample, pre-treatment sample set control. , normalize expression values gene -treatment sample -spot mean pre-treatment sample. analyzing pre-treatment sample, control sample unavailable. Just normalize expression values gene pre-treatment sample zero mean across spots. words, just regard ST sample control sample.
code: # extract count matrix expr_on <- as.matrix(SpaCET_obj_on@input$counts) expr_pre <- as.matrix(SpaCET_obj_pre@input$counts)  # normalize to TPM expr_on <- t(t(expr_on)*1e6/colSums(expr_on)) expr_pre <- t(t(expr_pre)*1e6/colSums(expr_pre))  # transform to log space expr_on <- log2(expr_on/10 + 1) expr_pre <- log2(expr_pre/10 + 1)  # normalized with the control samples expr_on_rmControl <- expr_on - rowMeans(expr_pre) expr_on_rmControl <- round(expr_on_rmControl,3)  expr_pre_rmControl <- expr_pre - rowMeans(expr_pre) expr_pre_rmControl <- round(expr_pre_rmControl,3)  # run SecAct to infer activity library(SecAct) res_on <- SecAct.inference(expr_on_rmControl) res_pre <- SecAct.inference(expr_pre_rmControl)

title: Infer secreted protein activity in spatial transcriptomics data
text: can integrate activity results SpaCET object, visiualize .
code: SpaCET_obj_on@results$activity <- res_on SpaCET_obj_pre@results$activity <- res_pre  library(patchwork) p1 <- SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj_pre, gene = "TGFB1", signalMode="receiving")  p2 <- SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj_on, gene = "TGFB1", signalMode="receiving")   p1|p2

what: Read ST data to a SpaCET object
title: Cell-cell communication for single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data
text: load data R, user can create SpaCET object preparing three types input data. count data. spatial transcriptomics count data must format matrix gene name (row) x cell ID (column). spatial location information. cell coordinates format matrix cell ID (row) x coordinates (column). 1st 2nd columns represent X Y coordinates, respectively. meta data (optional). meta data format matrix cell ID (row) meta annotation (column).  SpaCET_obj@metaData contains cell type annotation original study.
code: library(SecAct) library(SpaCET)  # download data from https://zenodo.org/records/15006880/files/LIHC_CosMx_data.rda # load CosMx data load("LIHC_CosMx_data.rda")  # show count matrix dim(counts) ## [1]   1000 460441  # show coordinate matrix spotCoordinates[1:5,]  ##             x_slide_mm y_slide_mm ## c_2_100_733    6.70816    9.03340 ## c_2_101_240    7.50024    8.86156 ## c_2_101_339    7.60560    8.73604 ## c_2_101_452    7.62984    9.17260 ## c_2_102_179    7.86824    8.99368  # show meta information metaData[1:5,]  ##                    cellType         niche ## c_2_100_733      Tumor_core tumor subtype ## c_2_101_240 Tumor_interface     interface ## c_2_101_339      Tumor_core         tumor ## c_2_101_452      Tumor_core tumor subtype ## c_2_102_179      Tumor_core         tumor   # create a SpaCET object SpaCET_obj <- create.SpaCET.object(   counts = counts,   spotCoordinates = spotCoordinates,   metaData = metaData,   imagePath = NA,   platform = "CosMx" )  # show this object. str(SpaCET_obj)   # filter out cells with less than 50 expressed genes SpaCET_obj <- SpaCET.quality.control(SpaCET_obj, min.genes=50)  ## [1] "Removing cells with less than 50 expressed genes." ## [1] "16926 cells are removed." ## [1] "443515 cells are kept."  # plot the QC metrics SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(   SpaCET_obj,    spatialType = "QualityControl",    spatialFeatures=c("UMI","Gene"),   imageBg = TRUE,   pointSize = 0.1 ) # show the spatial distribution of all cell types my_cols <- c(   'B'='#C88888','Erythrocyte'='#fe666d','T.alpha.beta'='#B95FBB','T.gamma.delta'='#3288bd',   'NK'='#bb8761','Hepatocyte'='#63636d','Cholangiocyte'='#de77ae','Endothelial'='#D4D915',   'Fibroblast'='#66c2a5','Macrophage'='#ff9a36','Tumor_core'='#A4DFF2','Tumor_boundary'='blue',   'Other'='#cccccc' )  SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(   SpaCET_obj,    spatialType = "metaData",    spatialFeatures= "cellType",   colors = my_cols,   pointSize = 0.1 )

title: Cell-cell communication for single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data
text: loading ST data, user can run SecAct.activity.inference.ST infer signaling activities secreted proteins spot. output stored SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity, includes four items, (1) beta: regression coefficients; (2) se: standard error; (3) zscore: beta/se; (4): pvalue: two-sided test p value z score permutation test.
code: # infer activity; 60 minutes SpaCET_obj <- SecAct.activity.inference.ST(   inputProfile = SpaCET_obj,   scale.factor = 1000,   sigFilter=TRUE ) # The running times mentioned here and onwards were obtained # from our HPC with 20 cores and 200 GB of memory.  # show activity SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity $zscore[1:6,1:3]  ##        c_2_100_733 c_2_101_240 c_2_101_339 ## ACE     -2.6108455   -4.567062  -4.6543737 ## ADGRE5  -0.6088185   -4.872711  -5.2642456 ## ADGRF1   0.9180645    3.529136   3.5651975 ## ADGRG1   0.2462677    5.180391   4.8956442 ## ADIPOQ   0.9923366   -3.456214  -4.7621093 ## ALCAM    2.7917693    2.157889   0.7981345

title: Cell-cell communication for single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data
text: calculating secreted protein activity, SecAct estimate consensus pattern inferred signaling activities across whole tissue slide. module contains two steps. First, SecAct filters 1248 secreted proteins identify significant secreted proteins mediating intercellular communication slide. achieve , SecAct calculate Spearman correlation secreted protein s signaling activity neighbor cells’ sum expression. p values adjusted Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) method false discovery rate (FDR). cutoffs r > 0.05 FDR < 0.01. Second, designed computational strategy statistically test whether type secreted protein s mediates intercellular communication cell type 1 cell type 2. Cell-type annotations retrieved original study. First, identified neighboring pairs cells, one cell cell type 1 cell type 2, based spatial proximity (distance < 20 μm). Among neighboring pairs, identified communicating pairs cells cell type 1 expressed RNA s (count > 0), cell type 2 exhibited signaling activity s (activity score > 0). calculated communication score cell type 1 → s → cell type 2, defined ratio communicating pairs total neighboring pairs. p-value Probability (random ratio >= real ratio), computed 1000 randomizations adjusted Benjamini–Hochberg procedure. randomization, randomly permuted cell IDs within cell type. cell type 1 → s → cell type 2 communication considered significant ratio > 0.2 FDR < 0.01.
code: # infer CCC SpaCET_obj <- SecAct.CCC.scST(     SpaCET_obj,     cellType_meta = "cellType",     scale.factor = 1000,     radius = 0.02,     ratio_cutoff = 0.2,     padj_cutoff = 0.01 )  # show output head(SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinCCC)

title: Cell-cell communication for single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data
text: provide two types visualization plot cell-cell communication, .e., heatmap circle plot. number heatmap represents count secreted proteins senders receivers.  User can select cell-cell communication interest SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinCCC visualize using SecAct.CCC.dot. need assign values sender, secretedProtein, receiver.
code: SecAct.CCC.heatmap(SpaCET_obj, row.sorted=TRUE, column.sorted=TRUE, colors_cellType=my_cols) SecAct.CCC.circle(SpaCET_obj, colors_cellType=my_cols) cellTypes <- c("Tumor_boundary","Fibroblast","Macrophage","Endothelial")  secretedProtein <- c(   "BGN","COL1A1","COL1A2","DCN","IGFBP5",   "LGALS1","LGALS9","LYZ","LUM","MGP",   "SPP1","THBS1","THBS2" )  SecAct.CCC.dot(   SpaCET_obj,    colors_cellType=my_cols,    sender=cellTypes,    secretedProtein=secretedProtein,    receiver=cellTypes )

title: Cell-cell communication for single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data
text: User can select cell-cell communication interest SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinCCC visualize using SecAct.signaling.velocity.scST. need assign values sender, secretedProtein, receiver.
code: SecAct.signaling.velocity.scST(   SpaCET_obj,    sender="Fibroblast",    secretedProtein="THBS2",    receiver="Tumor_boundary",    cellType_meta="cellType" )

what: Read ST data to a SpaCET object
title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: load data R, user can create SpaCET object using create.SpaCET.object.10X. Please make sure visiumPath points standard output folders 10x Space Ranger. ST data 10x/Visium, can use create.SpaCET.object instead [details].
code: library(SecAct) library(SpaCET)  # set the path to the data folder dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package="SecAct"), "extdata/")  # load ST data to create an SpaCET object visiumPath <- paste0(dataPath,"Visium_HCC/") SpaCET_obj <- create.SpaCET.object.10X(visiumPath = visiumPath)  # filter out spots with less than 1000 expressed genes SpaCET_obj <- SpaCET.quality.control(SpaCET_obj, min.genes = 1000)  # plot the QC metrics SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(   SpaCET_obj,    spatialType = "QualityControl",    spatialFeatures = c("UMI","Gene"),   imageBg = TRUE )

title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: loading ST data, user can run SecAct.activity.inference.ST infer activities 1248 secreted proteins spot. output stored SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity, includes four items, (1) beta: regression coefficients; (2) se: standard error; (3) zscore: beta/se; (4): pvalue: two-sided test p value z score permutation test.
code: # infer activity; 25 minutes SpaCET_obj <- SecAct.activity.inference.ST(   inputProfile = SpaCET_obj,   scale.factor = 1e+05 ) # The running times mentioned here and onwards were obtained # from our HPC with 20 cores and 200 GB of memory.  # show activity SpaCET_obj @results $SecAct_output $SecretedProteinActivity $zscore[1:6,1:3]  ##           50x102      3x43     14x94 ## A1BG    4.179847  2.193798 -1.082260 ## A2M     1.990219  7.513577  2.520423 ## A2ML1   0.838544  0.298118  3.453744 ## AADACL2 1.790729 -3.226144  2.709726 ## ABHD15  3.224051 -1.534522  2.073572 ## ABI3BP  1.588963  6.592146 13.925150

title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: calculating secreted protein activity, SecAct estimate consensus pattern inferred signaling activities across whole tissue slide. module contains two steps. First, SecAct filters 1248 secreted proteins identify significant secreted proteins mediating intercellular communication slide. achieve , SecAct calculate Spearman correlation spots’ signaling activity spots’ neighbors’ RNA expression. p values adjusted Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) method false discovery rate (FDR). cutoffs r > 0.05 FDR < 0.01. Second, SecAct employs Non-negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) estimate consensus signaling patterns. critical parameter NMF factorization rank k. User can assign number vector k, e.g., k=2:5. , SecAct.signaling.pattern find optimal number factors determined point preceding largest decrease silhouette value. take . Based pre-calculation, k=3 optimal number factors. save time, directly run k=3.  , SecAct can identify secreted proteins associated signaling pattern according matrix W NMF results. one secreted protein (represented row W), signaling pattern value least twice large pattern, designated dominant pattern protein.
code: # estimate signaling pattern; 3 minutes SpaCET_obj <- SecAct.signaling.pattern(SpaCET_obj, k=3)   # plot signaling pattern SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(     SpaCET_obj,      spatialType = "SignalingPattern",      spatialFeatures = "All",      imageBg = FALSE,     legend.position = "none",     colors=c("#03c383","#fbbf45","#ef6a32") ) # identify secreted proteins dominated by pattern 3 pattern.gene <- SecAct.signaling.pattern.gene(SpaCET_obj, n=3)  # show these genes head(pattern.gene)

title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: Several secreted proteins pattern 3 related epithelial-mesenchymal transition process, COL1A1, TGFB1, SPARC. integrating secreted protein-coding gene expression signaling activity, SecAct can also infer signaling velocity spatial spot, indicating direction strength secreted signaling. Let’s take SPARC example.
code: # show SPARC signaling velocity  SecAct.signaling.velocity.spotST(SpaCET_obj, gene = "SPARC") # show animated SPARC signaling velocity SecAct.signaling.velocity.spotST(SpaCET_obj, gene = "SPARC", animated=TRUE)

title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: current ST data, user also can run previous R package SpaCET estimate cell lineages spot. Click details. Based deconvolution results, can see interface region consists fibroblasts, macrophages, endothelial cells.
code: # deconvolve ST data SpaCET_obj <- SpaCET.deconvolution(   SpaCET_obj,    cancerType = "LIHC",    coreNo = 8 )  # show the spatial distribution of all cell types. SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(   SpaCET_obj,    spatialType = "CellFraction",    spatialFeatures = c(     "Malignant","CAF","Endothelial","Macrophage",     "Hepatocyte","B cell","T CD4","T CD8"),    sameScaleForFraction = TRUE,   pointSize = 0.1,    nrow = 2 )

title: Signaling patterns and velocities for multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics data
text: User also can run SpaCET.GeneSetScore estimate hallmark scores spot. Click details. can see Pattern 3 correlated epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
code: # run gene set calculation SpaCET_obj <- SpaCET.GeneSetScore(SpaCET_obj, GeneSets="Hallmark")  # visualize EMT SpaCET.visualize.spatialFeature(   SpaCET_obj,    spatialType = "GeneSetScore",    spatialFeatures = "HALLMARK_EPITHELIAL_MESENCHYMAL_TRANSITION",   legend.position = "right",   imageBg=TRUE,   pointSize=1.2 )

title: Authors and Citation

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ru B, Jiang P (2025). SecAct: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference. R package version 1.0.0, https://github.com/data2intelligence/SecAct.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SecAct: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference},   author = {Beibei Ru and Peng Jiang},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://github.com/data2intelligence/SecAct}, }

title: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference
text: SecAct R package designed inferring intercellular signaling activity secreted proteins gene expression profiles. Users can input multiple modalities expression data, including spatial, single-cell, bulk transcriptomics data. outputs inferred signaling activities 1248 secreted proteins spatial spot, individual cell, sample, depending input data type. Based inferred activities, SecAct provides multiple downstream application modules. spatial data, SecAct can infer signaling pattern signaling velocity secreted proteins. single-cell data, SecAct can infer intercellular communication network signaling flow source cells receiver cells. bulk data, SecAct can infer secreted protein risk scores large cohort linked clinical data, can infer secreted protein activities differentially regulated two phenotypes. functionalities terms explained formally following tutorials.

title: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference
text: install SecAct, recommend using devtools: user can install SecAct source code. Click download . package installed successfully Operating Systems: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.10 (Ootpa) macOS Sequoia 15.3.1 operating system already GSL installed, please follow one installation methods , depending operating system.
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("data2intelligence/SecAct") # install SecAct in the R environment. install.packages("Path_to_the_source_code", repos = NULL, type="source") # Linux (Ubuntu/Debian): sudo apt-get install libgsl-dev  # Linux (Fedora/RHEL-based): sudo dnf install gsl-devel  # macOS (Homebrew): brew install gsl

title: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference
text: C Library: GNU Scientific Library (GSL). R version >= 4.2.0. R packages: Matrix, ggplot2, patchwork, NMF, circlize, ComplexHeatmap, ggalluvial, networkD3, survival, survminer.

title: Secreted Signaling Activity Inference
code: library(SecAct)  dataPath <- file.path(system.file(package = "SecAct"), "extdata/") expr.diff <- read.table(paste0(dataPath, "Ly86-Fc_vs_Vehicle_logFC.txt")) res <- SecAct.activity.inference(inputProfile=expr.diff, is.differential=TRUE)  head(res$zscore)  ##            Change ## A1BG     7.588670 ## A2M     15.974063 ## A2ML1    3.303167 ## AADACL2 -1.789684 ## ABHD15  -5.353521 ## ABI3BP  18.785484

title: Secreted protein signaling velocity — SecAct.spatial.velocity
text: Calculate signaling velocity secreted proteins based activities.

title: Secreted protein signaling velocity — SecAct.spatial.velocity
code: SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj, gene, signalMode = "both")

title: Secreted protein signaling velocity — SecAct.spatial.velocity
text: SpaCET_obj SpaCET object. gene Gene symbol coding secreted protein. signalMode Mode signaling velocity, .e., "receiving", "sending", "".

text: ggplot2 object.

title: Secreted protein signaling velocity — SecAct.spatial.velocity
text: velocity direction starts source cell producing secreted protein moves sink cells receiving secreted protein signal. velocity magnitude represents product secreted protein-coding gene expression source cells signaling activities sink cells.

title: Secreted protein signaling velocity — SecAct.spatial.velocity
code: SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj, gene="TGFB1", signalMode="receiving") SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj, gene="TGFB1", signalMode="sending") SecAct.spatial.velocity(SpaCET_obj, gene="TGFB1", signalMode="both")
